turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: I am totally unappreciated in my time.  We can run the whole park from this room, with minimal staff, for up to three days.  You think that kind of automation is easy? Or cheap? You know anybody who can network eight Connection Machines and de-bug two million lines of code for what I bid this job?  Because I'd sure as hell like to see them try.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: I'm sorry about your financial problems.  I really am. But they are your problems.

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: You're right, John.  You're absolutely right. Everything's my problem.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: I will not get drawn into another financial conversation with you, Dennis.  I really will not.

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: I don't think there's been any debate.  There's no debate...my mistakes....

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: I don't blame people for their mistakes, but I do ask that they pay for them.

turns.speaker: NEDRY
turns.text: Thanks, Dad.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Why didn't I build in Orlando?

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: I'll keep an eye on it.  Maybe it'll swing south like the last one.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Ray, start the tour program.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Sustain winds 45 knots.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Tell them when they get back to the cars.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Thanks, Steve.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: There's no sign of him anywhere.

turns.speaker: HAMMOND
turns.text: Robert - - I wonder if perhaps you would be kind  good enough to take a gas jeep and bring back my grandchildren.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: We miss you.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Thanks for the presents.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: We love the presents.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: What's going to happen to the goat?  He's going to eat the goat?!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Excellent.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: I'm sorry - - I'm sorry - -

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Turn it off, Lex!  Turn it off!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: I don't know, I don't know.  I'm sorry - -

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Why did you do this?

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: I don't know!  I'm sorry!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Why are we hurrying if there's nothing wrong?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: What if we fall?  I hate trees.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: I hate trees!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: They don't bother me.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Yeah, you weren't in that last one.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: No, no, sh, sh, sh - - stop!  Stop! Stop!  Don't let the monsters come over here!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: They're not monsters, Lex. They're just animals.  And these are herbivores.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: That means they only eat vegetables.  But for you, I think they'd make an exception.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: I'm a hacker!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: That's what I said!  You're a nerd!  They don't call you people hackers anymore - - they call you people nerds!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Hey Lex, ahhhchooo!  Hey Lex, com here.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Hey Lex, you forgot to say gazundheit.

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: That's not funny.

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: That was great!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: Jump, Timmy!  It's too late!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: I'm afraid I am gonna fall!

turns.speaker: LEX
turns.text: You're gonna get electrocuted  electrified!  The power's coming back!

turns.speaker: TIM
turns.text: Shut up!  You're scaring me.  Stop!  You're scaring me.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Ken, it's Bruce. Listen, we've got a nibble on the Pendleton financing.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Really? How much?

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Fifty.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Fifty? We need seventy-five.

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Ken, we've been through this...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: You tell them if they come up to seventy-five, I'll cut them in on the Crystal Lake package.

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Don't tell me you're still thinking of buying Casa de Psycho...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Hey, smart-ass, I'm up here right now in a... luxury alpine retreat, with a two million dollar view of the lake.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Chain saws.

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: You want to put in chain saws?

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: No, no... listen, when I get back to New York we'll meet with the Board.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I don't think the people who live around here would like that very much...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Do you think they like the fact that tourism has dropped ninety-eight percent in the last ten years?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: No, but...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: And do you think they like the fact that half the country thinks Crystal Lake is filled with corpses?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: That's not true...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: We're not talking about truth, we're talking about perception. And the perception is that Crystal Lake means inbred psychopaths running around the hills with axes and hockey masks chopping up teenagers.  That, my dear, is what we call an _image problem_.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Beautiful trees... sturdy trunks... lots of branches...  We can do some great logging up here.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Logging? We'll need an environmental impact study for that...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: I don't think you're getting in the spirit of things, Janet. We'll buy whatever studies we need --

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Jesus Christ!

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Just a deer, Mister Biller. Part of the local wildlife.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Get rid of them.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Okay... well... I think it's this way...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Great.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Mister Biller?

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I think we're lost.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: You have a map.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I know... but we left the main trail... and I can't find any landmarks around here... I've been trying to figure it out but...

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I didn't think there were any houses up here...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: You learn something new every day. Let's go.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Structure might be salvageable... let's see what the interior looks like.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Mister Biller... now that we can see the lake, I think we should follow the shoreline to --

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: Help me with this.

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: There doesn't seem to be any water damage. Kind of cozy, actually.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I really think we should go back...

turns.speaker: BILLER
turns.text: I want to look at the rest of the house.

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Hello?

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Who is this? What's going on?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: This is Janet Davenport -- I'm the Realtor.

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Where's Ken? Is he all right?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: What about that other guy?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Other guy?

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Yeah. Ken said there was another guy there... _big_ guy... then he dropped the phone. What's going on?

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Janet, are you okay? Are you there?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: He... he's here...

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Who's there?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Oh my god... this is his house... _we're in his fucking house_...

turns.speaker: BRUCE'S VOICE
turns.text: Janet, goddamnit, what's going on?

turns.speaker: JANET
turns.text: Jas... Jason Voorhees... he's here...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Two.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: I'm not sure I'd call them murder exactly. More like a couple of bar fights that got out of hand.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I seem to recall arguing the same thing in court while you were trying to file murder-one charges.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: That's my job.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Quite a circus.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: And we're in the center ring.  You sure you want to wear that blazer?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: You're about to be a media darling -- you might want to dress the part.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Ruby, come on. You witnessed a brutal triple murder and you're having trouble accepting it.  Think about what you're saying. You really expect a jury to believe that Jason has a mystery killer living in his tummy?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I know how this sounds, but that's what happened.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: I can't wait to hear your opening argument.	"Ladies and Gentlemen	of the Jury... the Defense will prove that Jason Voorhees did not kill all of these people. They, in fact, committed mass suicide and then buried themselves in his back yard..."

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Fuck you.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What's going on?

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Some kind of emergency back at the Sheriff's Station. Four deputies shot... some kind of explosion... I don't know what's going on, but they're panicking back there.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It's still on.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: His camera... it's still recording.

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: _Krueger_...

turns.speaker: HARDING
turns.text: Who?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Come on.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Three.  Where's my client?

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Your... client is being booked right now. He'll be in cell five.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What are the charges?

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Shit. We're still putting the victim list together. You'll need a forklift for the case file. I suggest you hire some help, and don't expect to get a lot of sleep for the next few months.  You're about to defend the most notorious serial killer in American history.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I thought that was Ted Bundy.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Compared to this guy... amateur.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: A house?

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: That's right. Wasn't on any of the maps... we could barely see it through the underbrush. Place must've been abandoned for twenty years.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Ruby... this guy almost took out an entire Tactical Response Team. You can't expect me to just leave you --

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: He doesn't look like he's going anywhere, Bill. And if necessary, I can get a judicial order reaffirming the right of my client to speak to his attorney in private.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That's right... it... it came right out of his chest...

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Who's chest?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Jason's. It came out of his chest... a hand with long blades on the fingers...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: And this hand... it... it slashed Doctor Layton's throat... and the Deputy. Then it grabbed Danny by the head...  And it pulled his head right down into his chest... I couldn't... Hayes lays a hand his shoulder.

turns.speaker: HAYES
turns.text: Take it easy, Ruby...	it's all right.  Now, try to think clearly... don't you mean _Jason's_ hand... don't you mean he grabbed a scalpel and slashed Doctor Layton's throat?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Did you find a scalpel? Did you find a murder weapon?

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: Are you going to plead insanity?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I think it's our best bet. They're taking apart his house right now... they found weapons, blood, a mountain of evidence. We can't say he was framed.

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: Sorry.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It's all right.  Now... we're going to need a really good head-doctor for this. Someone who can get up on the stand and tell the jury that our client is mentally insane and has been for years...  We'll go through a dozen doctors before we find one who's willing to testify for us.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Now... I think the video store's open for another couple of hours. Let's go.

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: Video store?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: So... why can't Jason get a fair trial?

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: Because everyone knows he's guilty...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Wrong. Jason can't get a fair trial because of _these_.

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: You think that's going to work?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't know if anything's going to work in this case. Therefore, we have to try everything.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: You watch this garbage?

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: This is a legitimate cinematic genre. Just like Westerns, Comedies, Film Noire, Science Fiction...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: "Zombie Sluts From Beyond the Grave."

turns.speaker: KWAN
turns.text: A seminal film. First ever depiction of a fully nude triple impalement.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Well?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: He's fucking nuts.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Great. Is that what you're going to say when I put you on the stand?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: No. When you put me on the stand, I'll say your client is catatonic and exhibits classic symptoms of a schizophrenic, sociopathic personality.  And he doesn't sleep.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Doesnit sleep?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Insomnia. Not unusual for someone in his situation.  Not to mention he's a bed-wetter.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: He wets the bed?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: I always throw that in. It makes the jury feel sorry for the defendant.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: One of the deputies is pretty cute. I think she likes me.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: This is bad, Joe. The Prosecution is already putting together a team of psychiatric specialists. They'll argue exactly the opposite. They'll say he's just pretending to be catatonic and he's completely sane.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Great. Battling head doctors. We'll confuse the jury enough to create a reasonable doubt. Hung jury.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: This is Jason Voorhees. They'll be looking for an excuse to send him to the chair.  If we're going to argue insanity, we're going to need something a little more concrete.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Nurses. That's why I went into medicine.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: This sexual obsession of yours. Have you considered going into therapy yourself?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: No need. I'm self-diagnosed. I have severe nympholepsy...  And I'm a bed-wetter.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Well, I definitely feel sorry for you.  August fourteenth, 1956... Jason was brought in by his mother, who said the boy hadn't slept for two weeks. Doctor prescribed Valium...

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: I don't believe it. Jason's mother died of ovarian cancer in 1969.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: I thought she was a killer, too. You know... that she chopped up a bunch of teenage camp counselors... before she was decapitated.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That's the problem with this case. Everyone thinks they know Jason's life story. But they don't. What you're remembering is a _movie_. Fiction.	In the movie, Jason's mother runs around, killing people after Jason drowns in Crystal Lake

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: None of that's true?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Well, Jason _was_ in a canoe accident in 1967 and presumed drowned. His mother died a few years later after a long bout with cancer. Some time in the early eighties, there were a string of murders out by Crystal Lake...  People started saying it was Jason... back from the dead.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: So, what are you saying... that he didn't kill all those people?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: My job is not to determine his guilt or innocence. That's up to the jury. My job is defend him.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Don't get me wrong. I don't care. But the professional part of me is interested in how you rationalize what you do.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't "rationalize" anything. I'm his lawyer -- he's my client. That's all.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: That didn't sound very convincing.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What do you want -- a tidy psychological profile? You want to hear that I was falsely accused of a crime I didn't commit... and that's driven me to defend others? Or maybe you want to me to get in touch with my feelings... talk about my childhood...

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: No. You've told me all I need to know.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: You're obviously going through a critical moral dilemma. And you're putting up barriers against anyone who tries to probe your conscience.  But it is heartening to know that you do have a conscience.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Not much here. Jason was brought in a couple more times for insomnia... that's about it.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Wait a minute. Let me see that. She hands him the file.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: The mother said the boy hadn't slept for over three _months_. A physical examination showed dilated pupils, temperature of one-oh-two, blood chemistry highly imbalanced...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That's pretty weird. Is it possible for someone to not sleep for months?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: It's rare... but there are cases where people go for years without sleep.  They diagnosed Jason with simple insomnia... but that's not what it looks like to me. He has every indication of having _insomnolesence_.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Insomnolesence...

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: It's a neurological disorder affecting the hypothalamus. The part of the brain that causes sleepiness is inactive. They didn't know about it back in the sixties. Even now, it's not understood very well.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: So Jason doesn't sleep... how does that help us?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Insomnolesence has been known to cause psychotic episodes... delusions...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: If we could prove that Jason suffers from this disorder... and that his homicidal behavior has been a direct result of a medical condition...

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Not guilty by reason of insanity. Case closed.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: How do we prove it?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Simple. We sedate him, induce a somnolesent state, and study his REM patterns when he's unconscious.  If he has the disorder, his REMS will be highly abnormal. Ruby smiles.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Then I'd say it's bedtime for Jason.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: How long will he need to be asleep?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: We're going to need at least two full REM cycles to get a clear neurological profile. Three hours minimum, six hours ideal.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Well, that's it. He'll be asleep in a few minutes, but his first REM-cycle probably won't kick in for another hour or so.  Is there a place we can get something to eat in this town?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: There's a pizza place over on Market.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Cute waitresses?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That's open to debate.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: I'll take my chances. Come on, I'm buying.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: There's nothing to see here. He sleeps... we record it. That's all that happens.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: He's my client, and this is important. Enjoy your waitresses.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I think I'm onto something, Joe.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Me too. I'm drunk.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Well, I'm onto something more useful.  You ever hear of a man named Fred Krueger?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Krueger... doesn't ring a bell.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: He was a child killer in the late sixties... in a town called Springwood about eight miles from here.  Guess what his murder weapon was? A glove with six-inch blades.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Fascinating.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Now.... according to the file, Krueger was burned to death in a fire in 1968. But get this -- beginning in 1984, there was _another_ series of murders in Springwood. All teenagers... all killed in their sleep... all killed with finger blades just like Krueger's.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: I thought you said Krueger burned to death.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That's right. The murders in the eighties were never solved.  But... there were teenaged witnesses who said Krueger had the ability to appear in your dreams... and that if he killed you in a dream, it would kill you in the real world.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Uh-huh...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Don't you see? Jason was _asleep_. And he was dreaming -- the REM patterns prove that. And I saw finger blades just like Krueger's come out of Jason's chest. There has to be a connection.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Yeah... I think I understand...  You're drunk, too.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: See this?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Yeah, what is it?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: _It's a second REM pattern_.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: It's as though there were two people in that room... both of them asleep... both of them dreaming.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: That doesn't make sense.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Add it to the list.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: So what do we do?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: I don't suppose I can go back to the University and chase young coeds again... pretend this whole thing never happened...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Then I'd say we should put Jason under again... run another tape on him and see what happens. We'll get extra data this time. Video... infrared... the works.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Great.	When can you do it?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Tomorrow. If you can clear it with the Sheriff's department.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I'll have to lean on them pretty hard after what happened last night... but I think I can do it.  Let me know what happens.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: You're not going to be there?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I was there once... that was enough. Besides... I have to go out to Jason's house tomorrow.  They're... digging up some new evidence.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: It's all right. I'm simply in shock... this is what happens to people when they experience events they can't understand or comprehend. The mind shuts down temporarily and tries to shield itself from the horrific imagery it's been exposed to.  I'm going to need a lot of therapy.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: It was Krueger, wasn't it?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: You saw him?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: A cameraman caught him on videotape. Joe, I saw an entire sheriff's squad fighting and losing against an enemy that wasn't there...

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Checking out a theory. Just keep talking to him.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: This is Jason's REM pattern... and this is the boy's REM pattern. They're identical.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: How's that possible?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Jason's asleep... maybe he's dreaming of himself as a young boy... and that boy is sitting right here.  I think he's some kind of projection from Jason's subconscious.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: So Krueger thinks Jason's dead... leaves him in the lake... but the boy actually wakes up on the shore... crawls off into the woods... where he lives the rest of his life alone.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Alone... but with a murderous fury inside him... which led him to kill dozens of people.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: If I'm right, this happened before the Krueger murders in Springwood.  That means that Jason might've been Krueger's first victim.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Except this victim got away. I wonder if --

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Where's he going?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I don't know... but I think he's pissed.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Great. Now there's _two_ serial killers on the loose.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Krueger's the greater danger right now. We have to stop him.  _Springwood_. That's where he'll go. That's where he's always gone.	But Springwood's not like Crystal Lake. There's a couple hundred thousand people there. He could be anywhere.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: You know how to use one of those?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: I used to go hunting with my father when I was a kid.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Think it'll do any good?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Krueger's in the real world... maybe he's mortal, like us.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: And if he's not?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Then we're all in a lot of trouble.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: _Neurolar_. It's a stimulant -- it's also a serotonin inhibitor. It suppresses all electrical activity in the hippocampus... the part of the brain that controls dreaming.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: So you think it might counteract Krueger's ability to make us hallucinate?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: Ten CC's of this shit and you won't be dreaming about anything.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: How long will the effect last?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: About ten minutes.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Ten minutes...

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: If I give you a bigger dose, it'll give you a heart attack.

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: We're down to seven minutes.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Let's split up. You take the left side, I'll take the right. We'll meet in front of the Cineplex.

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: Are you all right?

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: For the moment! You've only got about two minutes left! Hurry! Ruby takes off towards the Cineplex...

turns.speaker: SENA
turns.text: What happened? Where's Jason?

turns.speaker: RUBY
turns.text: My client... is dead.  But I think he's a free man.

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: -- I'm hoping to live in the Old Quarter.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Even the so-called New Town isn't so new.  Only the people.  People of the future living in buildings of the past.  Has anyone seen Eduard?

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: You work in the insurance department?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You have been hearing the sordid side then.

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: Where do you live?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Up there.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: It's only majestic from here. When you get closer you see it for what it really is.

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: What is it really?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: A glorified office block.  They keep all the old records there -- the final resting place for facts and figures that have ceased to matter in the world of the living.

turns.speaker: ANNA
turns.text: Well, as long as I admire it from afar it shouldn't worry me if it's hollow.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: My assistants, I presume.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANTS
turns.text: Yes -- that's us.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: You look like brothers.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANTS
turns.text: Yes -- we do.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Have you worked here long?

turns.speaker: ASSISTANTS
turns.text: No, no, no -- quite a long time, yes.

turns.speaker: ASSISTANTS
turns.text: Fine -- terrible.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: What was the matter with it?

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: Heralds of a new age -- does that sound immodest?

turns.speaker: BEARDED ANARCHIST
turns.text: You could say we represent the <u>un</u>official view of a well-ordered society.

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: Preliminary investigations may already be underway.

turns.speaker: BEARDED ANARCHIST
turns.text: You were his friend.  One link is all they need.

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: -- Merely in the interests of order.

turns.speaker: BEARDED ANARCHIST
turns.text: The formality of a trial would be too costly for them.  They're beginning to understand that it's the ensuing news of our actions that incites support.

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: -- Ah, but what if it <u>wasn't</u>?

turns.speaker: BEARDED ANARCHIST
turns.text: -- Small.

turns.speaker: POCKMARKED ANARCHIST
turns.text: Yours is a very powerful and important firm -- it has a lot at stake.

turns.speaker: BEARDED ANARCHIST
turns.text: Perhaps Eduard was closer than he knew to discovering it and so had to be silenced.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: I've read your stories.  They're fantastic.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I don't know what you could have read.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Just what you've published.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: -- In magazines nobody reads.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: I read the one about the penal colony.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Did you?

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: The needles inscribing the judgement into the flesh of the man.  Very good.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Gabriela was right -- it's easier for me to understand suicide. I'm a practicing suicide.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: -- In what sense?

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: These strange stories you write -- they come naturally, do they?

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: Naturally? -- that's not the word I would have chosen.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Where do you get your ideas?  Only joking -- I'm just joking.  Let's go to a brothel then, Kafka, come on.

turns.speaker: KAFKA
turns.text: I haven't got the energy.  I mean, I have to conserve my energy.

turns.speaker: BIZZLEBEK
turns.text: Why do you work in that hideous insurance office?  -- dealing with people who fall off ladders.  Now take me -- I make my living as a stone mason.  It's not my art -- but it's the <u>tools</u> of my art.  You could be -- a journalist.
